New York University Archives
New York University Archives Collection of Course Bulletins
New York University
MC.286
130 Linear Feet in 378 bound volumes and 195 boxes
0.34 Gigabytes
247 websites in 247 archived websites.
1832-ongoing The collection consists of publications (bulletins, catalogs, announcements, etc.) that outline the course of study at New York University and its component schools, dating from 1832 to the present day. The publications are a mix of bound and unbound materials, as well as electronic records in the PDF format and websites containing details about course offerings at NYU. They typically include an overview of the school, degree requirements, lists of faculty and administrators, and course descriptions. Early publications sometimes include lists of students and degrees conferred.
Conditions Governing Access
Material pertaining to individual student records may be restricted in accordance with the Family Educational Rights and Privacy Act (FERPA). Please contact the Archives with specific questions regarding access to such records.
Conditions Governing Use
Materials in this collection which were created prior to 1924 are in the public domain. Permission to publish or reproduce is not required.
Materials that were published in 1924 or later are potentially protected by copyright and/or related rights. You are free to use materials in the collection in any way that is permitted by the copyright and related rights legislation that applies to your use. For other uses you need to obtain permission from the rights-holder(s).
Existence and Location of Copies
Additional duplicate copies of publications are held in the collection of New York University Publications (preservation copies) (RG 1.0).
Immediate Source of Acquisition
Materials found in collection; provenance is unknown. Material from 2020 accretion was donated by Richard Carreno in July 2019. The accession number associated with this donation is 2020.003.
Prior to 2018, websites were initially selected by curators and captured through the use of the Internet Archive's Archive-it service. Archive-It uses web crawling technology to capture websites at a scheduled time and displays only an archived copy, from the resulting WARC file, of the website. In 2019, accessioning information for archived websites were recorded. Websites were added either due to content drift, link rot, or were selected by the University Archivist. The accession numbers associated with these websites are 2019.090, 2019.091, 2019.092, 2019.098, 2019.099, 2019.100, 2019.101, 2019.102, 2019.103, 2019.104, 2019.105, 2019.117, 2019.127, 2019.129, 2019.132, 2020.003, 2020.010, 2020.022, 2020.024, 2020. 026, 2020.028, 2020.031, 2021.010, 2021.013, 2021.018, 2021.023, 2021.024, 2021.025, 2021.026, 2021.027, 2021.028, 2021.029, 2021.030, 2021.031, 2021.032, 2021.034, 2021.035.
Preferred Citation
Identification of item, date; New York University Archives Collection of Course Bulletins; MC 286; box number; folder number; New York University Archives, New York University.
To cite the archived website in this collection: Identification of item, date; New York University Archives Collection of Course Bulletins; MC 286; Wayback URL; Repository Name, New York University.
Arrangement
The collection is organized into series based on the New York University Archives's record group classification system, then by date. Titles for the record groups are based on the school or program's current official name (as of 2019). For example, School of Commerce bulletins are included as part of the Stern School of Business record group.
Scope and Contents
The collection consists of publications (bulletins, catalogs, announcements, etc.) that outline the course of study at New York University and its component schools, dating from 1832 to the present day. The publications are a mix of bound and unbound materials, as well as electronic records in the PDF format and websites containing details about course offerings at NYU. They typically include an overview of the school, degree requirements, lists of faculty and administrators, and course descriptions. Early publications sometimes include lists of students and degrees conferred.
Processing Information
This collection was assembled by the New York University Archives staff. It was collectively referred to as "Series 3: Bulletins, Catalogs, Announcements" through 2018. This designation may appear on boxes and folders in the current collection.
In May 2019 additional course bulletins were discovered in the University Archives and were integrated into this collection.
In 2021, the archived websites captured in the University Archives: Course Listings, Bulletins and Descriptions Archive-it Collection were integrated into MC 286 according to record group.

Courant Institute Educational Programs Archived Website: May 2014-May 2016
Scope and Contents
Courant Institute of Mathematical Sciences is a center for research and advanced training in mathematics and computer science. The Institute has long been a leader in mathematical analysis, applied mathematics, and scientific computation, with special emphasis on partial differential equations and their applications. In computer science, the Institute excels in theory, programming languages, computer graphics, and parallel computing. Mathematics and computer science are viewed as living parts of the stream of science, not as isolated specialties. They offer Master of Science (M.S.) and Ph.D. programs in both mathematics and computer science. Courant is affiliated with the Graduate School of Arts and Science.Master of Science Program Mathematics in FinanceJuly 2014-September 2016Electronic Records

Polytechnic Undergraduate and Graduate Bulletin (with addenda) Archived Website: May 2014-August 2018
Scope and Contents
The New York University Polytechnic School of Engineering bulletin/catalog is an official publication of NYU. It provides information about academic programs and a summary of Institute policies and procedures and selected activities and services. Information concerning admission, academic regulations and requirements, student services, academic offerings and a listing of administrative officers and faculty are included. Every effort has been made to publish a complete and accurate catalog. However, requirements, deadlines, tuition, fees, curricula, courses and staffing are subject to change at any time without advance notice or obligation. Some course descriptions may vary from actual course content because of advancements in the discipline, emphasis of individual instructors or decisions of the faculty to change the scope or content of the course. NYU Polytechnic School of Engineering is a comprehensive school of engineering, applied sciences, technology and research, and is rooted in a 158-year tradition of invention, innovation and entrepreneurship. The institution, founded in 1854, is the nation's second-oldest private engineering school. In addition to its main campus in New York City at MetroTech Center in downtown Brooklyn, it also offers programs at sites throughout the region, around the globe and remotely through online learning. The NYU School of Engineering is an integral part of NYU Abu Dhabi, NYU Shanghai, and the NYU Center for Urban Science and Progress (CUSP) in downtown Brooklyn.Tandon School of Engineering Undergraduate and Graduate BulletinApril 2015-ongoingElectronic Records
